00:01:22.070 --> 00:01:23.669

00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:03.760
DOC, aside from chemotherapy and radiation therapy,

00:00:03.820 --> 00:00:06.520
are there other treatment methods for cancer?

00:00:06.580 --> 00:00:08.920
Hi, I'm Doctor Edilene,

00:00:09.020 --> 00:00:11.000
your nuclear medicine specialist.

00:00:11.180 --> 00:00:13.860
And welcome to ask your TMC DOC.

00:00:13.861 --> 00:00:15.401
That's a great question.

00:00:15.620 --> 00:00:19.120
While most are familiar with chemotherapy and radiation therapy,

00:00:19.260 --> 00:00:21.760
there's actually another groundbreaking approach

00:00:21.820 --> 00:00:24.120
that takes treatment to the next level.

00:00:24.220 --> 00:00:28.840
Theranostics, a method which combines therapy and diagnostics

00:00:28.940 --> 00:00:31.440
using specialized radioactive tracers

00:00:31.580 --> 00:00:35.020
to find cancer cells and deliver targeted treatment,

00:00:35.021 --> 00:00:37.761
all with precision and less side effects.

00:00:38.020 --> 00:00:39.400
Think of it this way,

00:00:39.580 --> 00:00:43.400
while chemotherapy attacks cells all over your body,

00:00:43.740 --> 00:00:48.420
theranostics target cancer cells whilst sparing healthy tissues.

00:00:48.421 --> 00:00:50.881
It's a game changer for the tired, cancer,

00:00:51.020 --> 00:00:54.740
neuroendocrine tumours, prostate cancer and many more.

00:00:54.741 --> 00:00:57.201
But Theronostics isn't just treatment.

00:00:57.220 --> 00:01:00.180
It's personalized care designed for you.

00:01:00.181 --> 00:01:02.521
The future of cancer treatment is precise,

00:01:02.780 --> 00:01:04.780
effective and happening now.

00:01:04.781 --> 00:01:08.781
Want to learn more? Call this number or leave a comment below

00:01:08.782 --> 00:01:11.741
and a TMC doctor will answer in the next episode.

00:01:11.742 --> 00:01:17.081
You can also like and follow our TMC accounts for more tips. Bye.

00:00:03.220 --> 00:00:05.097

00:00:05.098 --> 00:00:08.217

00:00:08.218 --> 00:00:09.217
I usually ask,

did anything bad happen?

00:00:10.977 --> 00:00:12.381

00:00:12.382 --> 00:00:14.496
like nausea or stomach issues

00:00:14.497 --> 00:00:15.802
or even activation

00:00:16.177 --> 00:00:18.802
like not sleeping well or being energized,

00:00:18.977 --> 00:00:20.482

00:00:20.777 --> 00:00:22.856
these are the things that you see at first,

00:00:22.857 --> 00:00:24.522

The benefit that you get of reducing your depression

00:00:28.161 --> 00:00:29.920
or anxiety comes later,

as the medication

00:00:31.281 --> 00:00:33.960
reaches a steady state level in your body

00:00:33.961 --> 00:00:36.538
and starts to have its therapeutic effect.

00:00:00.060 --> 00:00:02.220
10 little habits that worsen your mental health

00:00:02.221 --> 00:00:03.681
from a licensed therapist.

00:00:03.740 --> 00:00:06.820
No. 1 scrolling your phone first thing in the morning.

00:00:06.821 --> 00:00:10.681
It over stimulates your brain before you even get ready for the day.

00:00:10.900 --> 00:00:14.260
Instead, try connecting with a person or even a pet

00:00:14.261 --> 00:00:17.561
and wait 30 minutes before using electronic devices.

00:00:17.800 --> 00:00:19.860
No.2 staying inside all day.

00:00:19.861 --> 00:00:21.681
This causes you to feel disconnected,

00:00:21.700 --> 00:00:24.200
sluggish, and often get more anxious.

00:00:24.340 --> 00:00:25.340
Instead, go outside,

00:00:25.341 --> 00:00:29.401
even for five minutes. Sunlight and fresh air make a real difference.

00:00:29.420 --> 00:00:31.680
No. 3 constantly watching the news.

00:00:31.681 --> 00:00:34.321
It overloads you with negativity and fear.

00:00:34.420 --> 00:00:37.720
Instead, limit news to once a day from a trusted source.

00:00:37.780 --> 00:00:40.420
No. 4 over comparing yourself to others.

00:00:40.421 --> 00:00:43.961
It distorts your reality and slowly chips away at your self esteem.

00:00:44.180 --> 00:00:46.260
Instead, limit your time on social media

00:00:46.261 --> 00:00:50.061
and use comparisons as a way to learn not to put yourself down.

00:00:50.062 --> 00:00:52.021
No. 5 constantly complaining.

00:00:52.022 --> 00:00:54.481
This traps your brain in a cycle of negativity.

00:00:54.660 --> 00:00:56.900
Instead, set a timer to vent or worry,

00:00:56.901 --> 00:01:00.161
but once the time is up, shift to useful thinking.

00:01:00.360 --> 00:01:02.340
No.6 not moving your body.

00:01:02.341 --> 00:01:04.821
It lowers your energy and makes you feel sluggish.

00:01:04.822 --> 00:01:08.321
Instead, take a short walk or stretch every few hours.

00:01:08.400 --> 00:01:11.740
No.7 eating whatever's convenient instead of what's good for you.

00:01:11.741 --> 00:01:14.501
What you eat has a direct impact on your energy levels,

00:01:14.502 --> 00:01:16.221
which affects your mood, focus,

00:01:16.222 --> 00:01:18.381
and motivation. Instead,

00:01:18.382 --> 00:01:20.581
prep a few balanced meals or snacks in advance

00:01:20.582 --> 00:01:22.681
to make healthier choices easier.

00:01:22.780 --> 00:01:24.340
No.8. Overspending.

00:01:24.341 --> 00:01:27.121
It gives you short term happiness but long term stress.

00:01:27.300 --> 00:01:30.980
Instead, budget for small treats so you can enjoy them without guilt.

00:01:30.981 --> 00:01:31.701
No.. 9.

00:01:31.702 --> 00:01:33.421
Saying yes when you mean no.

00:01:33.422 --> 00:01:36.041
Doing so builds resentment and emotional fatigue.

00:01:36.300 --> 00:01:39.680
Instead, allow yourself to possibly disappoint others.

00:01:39.740 --> 00:01:42.020
It won't be the end of the world.

00:01:42.021 --> 00:01:42.661
No. 10.

00:01:42.662 --> 00:01:44.701
Ignoring your feelings. They don't go away,

00:01:44.702 --> 00:01:47.681
they build up and you become disconnected from yourself.

00:01:48.220 --> 00:01:51.880
Instead, learn to lean into them and allow them to exist.

00:00:00.040 --> 00:00:04.140
Here are three signs of high functioning depression.

00:00:04.640 --> 00:00:07.220
No. 1 being numb.

00:00:08.000 --> 00:00:11.460
We can get to the point that we just don't feel.

00:00:11.560 --> 00:00:12.680
Sometimes people will say,

00:00:12.680 --> 00:00:13.560
that's a strength.

00:00:13.560 --> 00:00:15.300
I just don't feel anything.

00:00:15.600 --> 00:00:16.760
It's not a strength.

00:00:16.760 --> 00:00:20.040
It means that our heart is overly defended

00:00:20.040 --> 00:00:21.300
and shut down.

00:00:22.000 --> 00:00:25.200
No.2 second sign of high functioning depression

00:00:25.200 --> 00:00:28.020
is the resignation and a hopelessness

00:00:28.280 --> 00:00:31.400
that we just become resigned to.

00:00:31.400 --> 00:00:33.040
This is how it's going to be,

00:00:33.040 --> 00:00:34.000
and we can function,

00:00:34.000 --> 00:00:34.800
we can perform,

00:00:34.800 --> 00:00:36.300
we can do things,

00:00:37.200 --> 00:00:40.020
but there's not a sense of hope about the future.

00:00:41.200 --> 00:00:43.520
The third sign of high functioning depression

00:00:43.520 --> 00:00:46.500
is the coping strategies that we develop.

00:00:46.840 --> 00:00:49.300
Addictions, avoidance,

00:00:50.000 --> 00:00:50.940
distraction

00:00:51.160 --> 00:00:52.240
that we develop.

00:00:52.240 --> 00:00:56.400
These ways of not feeling our feelings, and often

00:00:56.400 --> 00:00:59.340
these distractions and avoidances and addictions

00:00:59.600 --> 00:01:01.800
cause even more harm

00:01:01.800 --> 00:01:04.020
and even more suffering in our lives.

00:01:04.560 --> 00:01:06.960
To learn how to get free from high functioning

00:01:06.960 --> 00:01:08.880
depression, do follow my account

00:00:04.421 --> 00:00:07.781

00:00:07.782 --> 00:00:10.581
criteria of borderline personality disorder.

00:00:10.582 --> 00:00:13.941
Around 50% of people with BPD engage in self harm.

00:00:13.942 --> 00:00:16.361
And it's not always about wanting to die.

00:00:16.362 --> 00:00:18.021
Can be a way to regulate emotions,

00:00:18.022 --> 00:00:20.021
to feel real when nothing else does,

00:00:20.022 --> 00:00:22.221
to feel something when you're feeling nothing.

00:00:22.222 --> 00:00:24.901

00:00:24.902 --> 00:00:29.141
and the need to control when the emotions feel so out of control.

00:00:29.142 --> 00:00:33.241
People with B P D. May experience sensory processing differently,

00:00:33.480 --> 00:00:36.020
so the pain that they cause to themselves

00:00:36.021 --> 00:00:38.921
may feel different than the pain caused by others,

00:00:38.980 --> 00:00:42.720
therefore controlling the pain and at times masking it.

00:00:42.721 --> 00:00:46.301
Some people with BPD have a larger emotional

00:00:46.302 --> 00:00:50.101
amygdala response to negative things happening in their life.

00:00:50.102 --> 00:00:53.461
So just like almost everything else with a human condition,

00:00:53.462 --> 00:00:56.181
these symptoms live on a spectrum.

00:01:00.182 --> 00:01:03.541
and it can be hard to determine when an attempt will be made.

00:01:03.542 --> 00:01:08.701

00:01:08.702 --> 00:01:10.941
versus be an acute situation.

00:01:10.942 --> 00:01:13.241
And at the same time,

00:01:13.260 --> 00:01:17.500
up to 10% of people with BPD end up taking their life.

00:01:17.501 --> 00:01:21.501

00:01:21.502 --> 00:01:23.421

00:01:26.702 --> 00:01:30.421

missed if you're only looking for this criteria.

Do you or someone you know

00:00:01.120 --> 00:00:03.839
possibly have borderline personality disorder?

00:00:03.840 --> 00:00:04.919
Here are the key features

00:00:04.920 --> 00:00:06.479
an intense fear of abandonment,

00:00:06.480 --> 00:00:08.999
even going to extreme measures to avoid it,

00:00:09.000 --> 00:00:10.999
whether it's real or just imagined.

00:00:11.000 --> 00:00:12.239
A pattern of unstable,

00:00:12.240 --> 00:00:13.719
intense relationships,

00:00:13.720 --> 00:00:16.039
such as idealizing someone one minute and then

00:00:16.040 --> 00:00:18.439
as soon as that person falls short on something,

00:00:18.440 --> 00:00:20.079
seeing them as totally bad.

00:00:20.080 --> 00:00:22.900
Rapid changes in self identity and self image,

00:00:22.920 --> 00:00:24.679
sometimes even shifting their goals,

00:00:24.680 --> 00:00:25.839
shifting their values,

00:00:25.840 --> 00:00:27.279
reviewing themselves as bad,

00:00:27.280 --> 00:00:29.759
or sometimes even feeling as if they don't exist at all.

00:00:29.760 --> 00:00:30.839
Periods of paranoia

00:00:30.840 --> 00:00:33.239
that seem to be related to being stressed

00:00:33.240 --> 00:00:35.439
and a loss of contact with reality,

00:00:35.440 --> 00:00:37.839
which can last from a few minutes to a few hours.

00:00:37.840 --> 00:00:39.279
Impulsive and risky behaviors

00:00:39.280 --> 00:00:40.319
that are fun in the moment

00:00:40.320 --> 00:00:42.079
but have a high chance of danger,

00:00:42.080 --> 00:00:43.359
such as gambling,

00:00:43.360 --> 00:00:45.620
reckless driving, unsafe sex,

00:00:45.720 --> 00:00:46.759
spending sprees,

00:00:46.760 --> 00:00:48.620
binge eating, drug abuse

00:00:48.720 --> 00:00:51.679
or even sabotaging success by quitting a good job

00:00:51.680 --> 00:00:53.759
or ending a positive relationship.

00:00:53.760 --> 00:00:56.199
Suicidal threats or suicidal behavior

00:00:56.200 --> 00:00:57.700
or even self injury,

00:00:57.760 --> 00:00:59.599
often in response to the person

00:00:59.600 --> 00:01:01.799
fearing separation or abandonment.

00:01:01.800 --> 00:01:02.639
Wide mood swings.

00:01:02.640 --> 00:01:04.679
It can last from a few hours to a few days

00:01:04.680 --> 00:01:07.479
and can include intense happiness or irritability

00:01:07.480 --> 00:01:09.220
or shame or anxiety.

00:01:09.280 --> 00:01:10.879
Ongoing feelings of emptiness.

00:01:10.880 --> 00:01:11.719
And here's the kicker

00:01:11.720 --> 00:01:12.519
inappropriate

00:01:12.520 --> 00:01:13.439
intense anger,

00:01:13.440 --> 00:01:14.959
such as losing their temper,

00:01:14.960 --> 00:01:16.639
being sarcastic or bitter,

00:00:18.942 --> 00:00:20.421

00:00:20.422 --> 00:00:22.861
then what she's telling you is that emotionally,

00:00:22.862 --> 00:00:24.581
she's still very young. Now,

00:00:24.582 --> 00:00:27.261
you can absolutely still have a relationship with her.

00:00:27.262 --> 00:00:29.141
This isn't about cutting her off.

00:00:29.142 --> 00:00:32.401
This is about you learning to manage your own expectations.

00:00:32.720 --> 00:00:36.160
Your healing process is to become the mother you never had.

00:00:36.180 --> 00:00:38.100
You always needed an advocate,

00:00:38.101 --> 00:00:40.461
a protector, and someone to comfort you.

00:00:40.462 --> 00:00:42.801

00:00:42.980 --> 00:00:45.580
Your mother might be 50 or 60 years old,

00:00:45.581 --> 00:00:48.281
but emotionally, she's 7 or 10 years old.

00:00:48.320 --> 00:00:52.020

00:00:52.021 --> 00:00:53.381
and how you interact with her.

00:00:53.382 --> 00:00:56.061

00:00:56.062 --> 00:00:57.581

00:00:57.582 --> 00:00:59.181
to be able to understand your emotion,

00:00:59.182 --> 00:01:00.861
know what she's capable of giving,

00:01:00.862 --> 00:01:02.854
and protect yourself and your heart.

00:00:02.141 --> 00:00:05.181
and I'm also talking about a father that's in the home

00:00:07.662 --> 00:00:12.021

We start to believe that we weren't good enough

00:00:13.902 --> 00:00:16.081
or lovable enough to have him stay.

00:00:16.180 --> 00:00:19.260

because we can't relax.

00:00:34.880 --> 00:00:36.660

00:00:36.661 --> 00:00:37.861
we're gonna be abandoned.

00:00:44.062 --> 00:00:45.261
through an autoimmune disorder

00:00:45.262 --> 00:00:48.181
or other mystery illness. Because the truth is,

00:00:48.182 --> 00:00:50.181

00:00:53.222 --> 00:00:57.441

00:00:57.500 --> 00:01:00.460

00:01:00.461 --> 00:01:03.501

00:01:03.502 --> 00:01:06.401

00:00:43.000 --> 00:00:43.999

tilt their head,

00:00:46.040 --> 00:00:48.319

00:00:51.960 --> 00:00:54.079
to shoot the narkhand into their nose.

00:00:54.080 --> 00:00:54.759
After a few minutes,

00:00:54.760 --> 00:00:56.340
if the person does not respond,

00:00:56.360 --> 00:00:58.860
give them an additional dose in the other nostril.

00:00:58.920 --> 00:00:59.439
I believe that

00:00:59.440 --> 00:01:01.599
Narcan should be available in every school,

00:01:01.600 --> 00:01:03.159
hospital, and workplace.

00:01:03.160 --> 00:01:05.119
You can get naloxone from a pharmacy

00:01:05.120 --> 00:01:07.399
without a prescription in every state.

00:01:07.400 --> 00:01:09.199

00:00:00.100 --> 00:00:02.620
People are using this medication to treat fibromyalgia,

00:00:02.621 --> 00:00:05.521
long covid, autoimmune conditions and me.

00:00:05.660 --> 00:00:07.320
But is it actually beneficial?

00:00:07.420 --> 00:00:08.140
I'm Dr. Ray,

00:00:08.141 --> 00:00:10.461
a GP based in the UK, and this without doubt

00:00:10.462 --> 00:00:12.541
has been one of the most common questions people have been asking me

00:00:12.542 --> 00:00:13.721
of the last couple of weeks.

00:00:13.740 --> 00:00:15.620
And it's about low dose naloxone,

00:00:15.621 --> 00:00:17.301
or known as LDN. So

00:00:17.302 --> 00:00:20.741
LDN's licensed indication is treat people who are addicted to opioids

00:00:20.742 --> 00:00:25.481
such as morphine. And it starts at about 50 mg to 100 mg dosage per day.

00:00:25.540 --> 00:00:26.700
However, off license

00:00:26.701 --> 00:00:29.801
it can be used to help treat chronic pain conditions

00:00:29.940 --> 00:00:33.300
such as fibromyalgia. But this is usually a much lower dose,

00:00:33.301 --> 00:00:36.601
about 3 mg to around four and a/2 mg per day.

00:00:36.700 --> 00:00:37.740
Now, it's thought to work

00:00:37.741 --> 00:00:40.521
by blocking various cells in the body's immune system,

00:00:40.580 --> 00:00:42.260
which increases levels of endorphins,

00:00:42.261 --> 00:00:43.241
which is a hormone,

00:00:43.260 --> 00:00:47.080
and this is important in regulating pain and receptor thresholds.

00:00:47.460 --> 00:00:51.380
So this was the largest study I could find on LDN and fibromyalgia

00:00:51.381 --> 00:00:53.521
and included 431 patients.

00:00:53.820 --> 00:00:56.920
And the review included randomized controlled trials,

00:00:57.020 --> 00:00:59.340
case series and non RCTs as well.

00:00:59.341 --> 00:01:02.841
And it concluded that LDN does help with fibromyalgia pain.

00:01:02.860 --> 00:01:04.660
But it's important to note that the studies included

00:01:04.661 --> 00:01:08.601
weren't of great quality and the sample size was relatively small.

00:01:08.740 --> 00:01:10.620
So this is the most recent study I can find,

00:01:10.621 --> 00:01:12.921
which was done this year in 2024

00:01:12.940 --> 00:01:15.700
and include 99 people who had fibromyalgia.

00:01:15.701 --> 00:01:17.801
It randomly assigned them to two groups.

00:01:17.900 --> 00:01:20.680
One was treated With the 6 mg of LDN per day

00:01:20.820 --> 00:01:22.520
and one was treated with placebo.

00:01:22.660 --> 00:01:26.300
And I found there was no different between people treated with LDN

00:01:26.301 --> 00:01:29.821
and placebo. They did state that it did help memory problems

00:01:29.822 --> 00:01:32.141
in patient fibromyalgia. So as you can see,

00:01:32.142 --> 00:01:33.501
the evidence is a bit mixed

00:01:33.502 --> 00:01:34.761
and it's not conclusive

00:01:34.940 --> 00:01:37.680
as to whether LDN helps with fibromyalgia or not.

00:01:37.860 --> 00:01:38.340
But, you know,

00:01:38.341 --> 00:01:39.261
anecdotally speaking,

00:01:39.262 --> 00:01:42.181
I have seen patients on LDN who have reported fantastic results

00:01:42.182 --> 00:01:43.921
and it has really helped their fibromyalgia.

00:01:44.020 --> 00:01:44.620
On the flip side,

00:01:44.621 --> 00:01:47.761
I've also seen patients who are on it and not reported great results.

00:01:47.840 --> 00:01:48.500
Yes, absolutely.

00:01:48.501 --> 00:01:49.861
I think it's something worth exploring.

00:01:49.862 --> 00:01:51.521
If you're someone with fibromyalgia

00:01:51.580 --> 00:01:53.760
and you've tried a lot of treatments aren't working,

00:01:53.780 --> 00:01:55.200
it's something to maybe consider,

00:01:55.260 --> 00:01:56.380
but make sure you bring up with your doctor

00:01:56.381 --> 00:01:58.521
because not everyone is suitable for LDN

00:01:58.540 --> 00:02:01.040
and you need certain test done before you can start it.

00:02:01.300 --> 00:02:03.540
But just be mindful it's not a miracle cure for fibromyalgia,

00:02:03.541 --> 00:02:05.301
despite what you might see on the internet

00:02:05.302 --> 00:02:06.881
or TikTok or other platforms.

00:02:07.100 --> 00:02:08.860
But I think it's definitely a move in the right direction,

00:02:08.861 --> 00:02:10.341
and I think these discussions are great

00:02:10.342 --> 00:02:12.221
in helping us try and figure out a cure

00:02:12.222 --> 00:02:14.261
or treatment for fibromyalgia,

00:02:14.262 --> 00:02:16.841
because as of yet, there's not been a great move forward.

00:00:00.260 --> 00:00:02.300
So I think what this person was asking about

00:00:02.301 --> 00:00:03.541
is why

00:00:03.542 --> 00:00:08.341
a psychiatrist will sometimes give someone a tentative diagnosis

00:00:08.342 --> 00:00:12.461
or a maybe. We'll say somebody has a certain diagnosis,

00:00:12.462 --> 00:00:14.881
but we need to rule out other things.

00:00:15.020 --> 00:00:17.940
And we may say that we need additional observation time,

00:00:17.941 --> 00:00:20.221
or we need to talk to some more people.

00:00:20.222 --> 00:00:22.361
We call that collateral information,

00:00:22.500 --> 00:00:25.000
or that we need more testing of some sort.

00:00:25.220 --> 00:00:28.260
This person asked, is this a common thing that happens?

00:00:28.261 --> 00:00:29.101
And, yeah,

00:00:29.102 --> 00:00:32.181
it is pretty common. A lot of that has to do with the fact

00:00:32.182 --> 00:00:35.221
that mental health issues are so complicated,

00:00:35.222 --> 00:00:40.261
and we try to organize them based on diagnoses and symptoms

00:00:40.262 --> 00:00:43.301
as best we can. But even with that,

00:00:43.302 --> 00:00:44.701
it can be really tricky

00:00:44.702 --> 00:00:49.081
to tell what kind of diagnosis fits a person best sometimes.

00:00:49.500 --> 00:00:51.580
But insurance companies require,

00:00:51.581 --> 00:00:53.701
in order to pay for a visit,

00:00:53.702 --> 00:00:56.221
that we have some sort of diagnosis documented.

00:00:56.222 --> 00:00:57.381
So even if we're not sure,

00:00:57.382 --> 00:00:59.661
we have to take our best guess in the moment

00:00:59.662 --> 00:01:01.921
so that insurance will cover your visit.

00:01:02.140 --> 00:01:05.140
This kind of situation is especially common in people

00:01:05.141 --> 00:01:06.661
where we think they might have ADHD

00:01:06.662 --> 00:01:09.821
or autism, because these are neurodevelopmental disorders.

00:01:09.822 --> 00:01:10.581
And what that means

00:01:10.582 --> 00:01:14.141
is that they're gonna be relatively consistent over time.

00:01:14.142 --> 00:01:16.341
Doesn't mean they're gonna be looking the same

00:01:16.342 --> 00:01:17.861
in every single situation.

00:01:17.862 --> 00:01:21.801
But the symptoms kind of persist throughout someone's life.

00:01:21.980 --> 00:01:25.160
And of course, we're only seeing you for a snapshot of time.

00:01:25.180 --> 00:01:28.180
And if you have anything else that's going on at the same time.

00:01:28.181 --> 00:01:28.981
So, for example,

00:01:28.982 --> 00:01:32.861
an anxiety disorder that we think might be contributing, um,

00:01:32.862 --> 00:01:35.741
substance use that you're struggling with, depression,

00:01:35.742 --> 00:01:38.881
anything like that. Those are things that are more episodic,

00:01:38.940 --> 00:01:41.820
meaning they don't last typically forever.

00:01:41.821 --> 00:01:44.161
They kind of have a start and an end date,

00:01:44.260 --> 00:01:46.740
but during that time, they can really affect symptoms,

00:01:46.741 --> 00:01:49.001
and they can look a lot like other disorders.

00:01:49.340 --> 00:01:50.380
At the end of the day, though,

00:01:50.381 --> 00:01:53.541
things like autism, ADHD, depression,

00:01:53.542 --> 00:01:55.921
anxiety, all sorts of different things like that

00:01:56.260 --> 00:01:57.080
technically

00:01:57.100 --> 00:02:01.020
don't usually require a psychiatric testing for a diagnosis.

00:02:01.021 --> 00:02:04.041
There's something called clinical diagnosis,

00:02:04.180 --> 00:02:07.180
which just mean that based on our clinical expertise,

00:02:07.181 --> 00:02:08.541
we should be able to sit down with you,

00:02:08.542 --> 00:02:11.141
have a conversation, gather the information we need,

00:02:11.142 --> 00:02:14.661
and determine whether or not you fit with that diagnosis

00:02:14.662 --> 00:02:16.641
or that diagnosis fits with you.

00:02:17.020 --> 00:02:19.220
That being said, this stuff is so complicated,

00:02:19.221 --> 00:02:21.821
and there are definitely times when neuropsychiatric testing

00:02:21.822 --> 00:02:23.481
can be really, really helpful.

00:02:23.680 --> 00:02:25.060
So hopefully that answers your question.

00:02:25.061 --> 00:02:26.321
Just to kind of summarize,

00:02:26.380 --> 00:02:29.700
basically what it means is that we have to come up with a diagnosis

00:02:29.701 --> 00:02:32.401
for administrative or business purposes

00:02:32.460 --> 00:02:33.460
whether we like it or not.

00:02:33.461 --> 00:02:35.781
So even if it's not completely clear,

00:02:35.782 --> 00:02:38.161
we have to put our money down on something,

00:02:38.500 --> 00:02:41.860
take our best guess based on what we've seen.

00:02:41.861 --> 00:02:42.821
But at the end of the day,

00:02:42.822 --> 00:02:44.861
mental health issues are really complicated,

00:02:44.862 --> 00:02:47.301
and Everybody's experience is very unique

00:02:47.302 --> 00:02:50.529
and so we may not know for sure sometimes
